Sec. 141(b), Ala. Const. 2022, and Ala. Code 1975 §12-3-10, because it is
a timely appeal from a final judgment of the Tallapoosa Circuit Court
involving a domestic relations case, more specifically a divorce, that was
entered on February 27, 20241, which: (1) awarded the parties joint legal
custody of the minor children; (2) awarded Plaintiff [sole] physical
custody of the minor children; (3) awarded Defendant visitation
(Thursday pick up from school until Monday return to school every 1st
and 3rd week of the month); (4) awarded Defendant the 1st and 3rd full

(5) ordered that the Parties to alternate Christmas, Thanksgiving, and
Spring Break; (6) ordered each party would have the children for their
respective Mother’s or Father’s Day holiday; (7) ordered that the party

STATEMENT OF THE CASE
Nature of the Case
This case concerns a dispute between the Defendant Wife and
Plaintiff Husband as to whether it was in the best interest of the children
for Plaintiff to be awarded sole physical custody of the minor children and
Defendant to be awarded visitation given the evidence in this case. The
Plaintiff contended at trial that Defendant was abusive to their daughter,
A.K.M., and as a result the daughter feared Defendant. Defendant
contended at trial that she never abused A.K.M., and Plaintiff engaged
in parental alienation by purchasing expensive gifts for A.K.M. and
involving her in the divorce case, so that she would favor the Plaintiff.
Course of Proceedings
On September 18, 2023, Plaintiff filed his Complaint for Divorce in
the Tallapoosa Circuit Court based on a complete incompatibility of
temperament between the parties that they could no longer live together
as husband and wife. He requested custody of the minor children. C. 012-
014, Doc. 2. Contemporaneously filed with the Complaint for Divorce was
an Emergency Ex Parte Motion for Pendente Lite Relief alleging
Defendant physically abused their daughter and the children were not
8
safe with her. C. 015-016, Doc. 6. On that same day, the Court issued an
Ex Parte order awarding Plaintiff sole physical custody of the minor
children and exclusive use of the marital home, pendente lite. C. 017, Doc.
7.
On September 8, 2023, Defendant filed her Answer and
Counterclaim for Divorce denying all of Plaintiff’s allegations and
requesting sole physical custody of the children and possession of the
marital home. C. 019-022, Doc. 11. Contemporaneously filed with the
Answer and Counterclaim was a Motion to Set Aside the Ex Parte Order
and Defendant’s Motion for Pendente Lite Relief. C. 023-026, Doc. 14. On
September 11, 2023, the trial court set this matter for a pendente lite
hearing on September 12, 2023. C. 034, Doc. 37.On September 13, 2023,
Plaintiff filed an Answer to the Counterclaim. C. 036, Doc. 43.
On September 18, 2023, the trial court issued a pendente lite order
that kept sole physical custody with Plaintiff but gave Defendant set
visitation with the minor children and ordered Defendant to pay child
support. C. 047-048, Doc. 59. It also set the final trial for November 6,
2023. C. 047-048, Doc. 59.
9
The trial court conducted a bench trial on November 6, 2023. C. 071-
072, Doc. 143.
Disposition in the Court Below
On February 27, 2024, without making any findings of fact, the trial
court issued a Final Decree of Divorce which: (1) awarded the parties
joint legal custody of the minor children; (2) awarded Plaintiff [sole]
physical custody of the minor children; (3) awarded Defendant visitation
(Thursday pick up from school until Monday return to school every 1st
and 3rd week of the month); (4) awarded Defendant the 1st and 3rd full
weeks of June and July to exercise summer vacation with the children;
(5) ordered that the Parties to alternate Christmas, Thanksgiving, and
Spring Break; (6) ordered each party would have the children for their
respective Mother’s or Father’s Day holiday; (7) ordered that the party
not exercising his or her time with the children shall have the right to
call or Facetime them at least once a day; (8) ordered that Plaintiff shall
claim the children every year for income tax purposes; and (9) ordered
that Plaintiff shall maintain health and dental insurance on the minor
children. C. 092-099, Doc.156
10
Defendant filed a timely Motion to Alter, Amend, or Vacate the
Final Decree of Divorce pursuant to Ala.R.Civ.P. 59. C. 100-102, Doc. 161.
On March 21, 2024, Plaintiff filed an Answer to Defendant’s Motion to
Alter, Amend, or Vacate the Final Decree of Divorce. C. 103-104, Doc.
163. Thereafter, on July 26, 2024, Defendant’s undersigned counsel filed
a Notice of Appeal and Docketing Statement. C. 107-108, Doc. 107; C.
109-110, Doc. 109.
ISSUES PRESENTED FOR REVIEW
I. WHETHER THE TRIAL COURT ERRED TO
REVERSAL WHEN IT DETERMINED THE BEST
INTEREST OF THE CHILDREN WAS TO AWARD
SOLE PHYSICAL CUSTODY TO PLAINTIFF AND
VISITATION TO DEFENDANT?
II. WHETHER THE TRIAL COURT ERRED TO
REVERSAL WHEN IT AWARDED SOLE
PHYSICAL CUSTODY TO PLAINTIFF AND
VISITATION TO DEFENDANT WHEN THERE
WAS SUFFICIENT EVIDENCE TO OVERCOME
THE REBUTTABLE PRESUMPTION AGAINST
DEFENDANT HAVING CUSTODY?
STATEMENT OF THE FACTS
The trial court heard testimony presented by both sides on
November 6, 2023. At trial, the following was shown:
11
On direct examination by Plaintiff’s counsel, Plaintiff testified that
the Parties were married on May 3, 2018, and had two children together,
namely A.K.M., a daughter who was born on May 24, 2012, and B.M.M,
a son who was born on May 10, 2019. R. 7. See C. 012-014, Doc. 12.
Plaintiff testified that he and the Defendant worked as a team to get the
housework done during the years that they both were employed. R. 13.
Defendant was terminated around the months of August through
October 2021 and became a stay-at-home mother. R. 8. Plaintiff claimed
that after Defendant’s termination, she did not help around the house,
and he did most of the grocery shopping, cooking, and cleaning. R. 14.
However, Plaintiff admitted that the Defendant took on the
responsibility of taking the children to school and to their medical and
dental appointments. R. 14. R. 59. In fact, from the time the Parties’ son,
B.M.M. was born in 2019, until the time of the final trial in 2023, Plaintiff
had not taken him to any appointments. R. 60. Similarly, after the
Parties’ daughter, A.K.M., turned seven years old, Plaintiff had not been
to any of her appointments either. R. 61.
On direct examination by Defendant’s counsel, Defendant testified
that one major point of contention that led to their separation, and
12
ultimately their divorce, was the difference in how Plaintiff treated their
daughter compared to their son. R. 205. The Defendant did not agree with
how Plaintiff chose to parent. R. 164. She stated that the Plaintiff spent
most of his time focused on A.K.M., so the Defendant was the primary
caretaker for B.M.M. R. 164.
One specific situation that the Defendant recalled for the Court was
when Plaintiff decided to purchase a cellphone for their daughter when
she was about seven years old. R. 164. Defendant expressed her
disapproval of A.K.M. having a cellphone that young, but the Plaintiff
told her “Well, I’m going to do what I want to do. That’s my daughter.” R.
164. Since having the cellphone, Defendant has found A.K.M. using it for
inappropriate purposes such as making TikTok videos to songs with
explicit language that led to the cellphone being taken away as
punishment. R. 165. While the Parties would discuss the inappropriate
use of the cellphone, Plaintiff always allowed A.K.M. to have the
cellphone back. R. 165.
Defendant also provided testimony that Plaintiff would purchase
expensive gifts for A.K.M. throughout their marriage. Defendant also
stated that during the divorce, Plaintiff pushed A.K.M. away from her
13
and got closer to Plaintiff. R. 172. R. 185. Plaintiff admitted that both
dogs were purchased for A.K.M. R. 37. Also, during the pendency of the
divorce, Plaintiff redecorated A.K.M.’s room and bought her items from
her wish list that consisted of things such as: two pajama sets worth
$150.00, makeup, and other clothing items. R. 184. Plaintiff promised
A.K.M. that he would take her to a Taylor Swift concert. R. 78. Also,
shortly before the final trial, Defendant testified that she heard Plaintiff
tell their daughter that she could not go on her school field trip unless
Defendant agreed to settle the divorce case. R. 185.
Defendant testified that another area of contention was the
physical abuse she suffered. R. 167. Defendant testified that Plaintiff has
shoved her, knocked her on the couch, and pushed the couch over that
resulted in her falling on the floor. R. 168. She recounted an incident
where Plaintiff took her cellphone and went upstairs. R. 168. In response,
she followed Plaintiff upstairs and took his laptop as retaliation. R. 168.
He grabbed the laptop from her and hit her on the head with it, which
left a raised bump on her head. R. 168. R. 143. Then, Plaintiff spit on her.
R. 169. After the incident, Defendant showed her friend, Stacy Green
(“Green”), the bump. R. 143.
14
On direct examination of Green, she testified that she did recall
seeing Defendant with “quite a goose egg on the front of her head”, and
she was told by Defendant that Plaintiff hit her with a laptop. R. 143.
Green testified that Defendant did not seek medical treatment because
she was terrified that DHR would take her kids. R.144. According to
Green, Plaintiff was very controlling, and Defendant’s self-esteem
suffered because of it. R. 144. Green and Defendant had been friends
since before she was married to Plaintiff, and she knew that the Parties
were having marital issues. R. 141. R. 143. Other testimony provided by
Green was that Defendant was a wonderful mother. R. 146.
Contrary to Defendant’s testimony, Plaintiff claimed that the
Defendant’s abusive behavior towards him and A.K.M. led to him filing
for divorce. R. 8. Plaintiff testified that the day before he filed for divorce,
he witnessed Defendant put their daughter against the wall, slap her in
the face, and hit her in the mouth. R. 8. There was no testimony that law
enforcement was called.
Plaintiff testified that after he filed for divorce, A.K.M. attended her
friend, Brooklyn’s, birthday party. R. 49. Defendant was present at the
birthday party since she was close friends with Brooklyn’s mom, Porscha
15
Caldwell (“Porscha”). R. 49. R. 211. During the party, A.K.M. spent time
with Defendant. R. 49.
During Plaintiff’s cross examination by Defendant’s counsel,
Defendant’s counsel moved to admit two videos into the record. R. 49-52.
The videos were admitted. R. 52. Plaintiff testified that the first video in
the exhibit depicted A.K.M. and Defendant rocking in a rocking chair and
looking at a story on a cellphone together during the party. R. 49.
During Defendant’s direct examination by Defendant’s counsel, she
stated that she was not allowed to pick A.K.M. up and take her to the
birthday party, so Plaintiff had someone else take her. R. 182. When it
was time for A.K.M. to leave, Defendant noticed that A.K.M.’s demeanor
had changed, and she would no longer come around Defendant. R. 183.
A.K.M. waited by the road for Plaintiff to pick her up. R. 183. Defendant
noticed that any time she was around A.K.M. without Plaintiff they
bonded but when Plaintiff was around, A.K.M. did not engage with her.
R. 187.
Porscha testified that A.K.M. and Defendant had a great, normal
mother and daughter relationship. Porscha and Brooklyn spent summers
with A.K.M. and Defendant. R. 212.
16
As for the second video in the exhibit, Plaintiff testified that it was
B.M.M. facetiming Defendant to tell her that he loved her before bed. R.
51. Plaintiff admitted that this was something the children did every
night before bedtime. R. 51. This video was recorded after the divorce was
filed. R. 51. Defendant testified that during those calls, she would ask to
speak to A.K.M. and Plaintiff would tell her that she had to call A.K.M.’s
cellphone directly. R. 154. When Defendant tried to call A.K.M., her
number was blocked. R. 154.
Plaintiff’s counsel moved to admit Exhibit 9 into the record, and it
was admitted. R. 10. R. 11 Plaintiff testified that the exhibit depicted an
injury to A.K.M.’s arm caused by Defendant during an at-home dance
practice in the basement. R. 10. Plaintiff admitted that he was not
present in the basement. R. 10. Defendant testified that the injury was
caused by Plaintiff’s nephew, Landon, who likes to play rough with
A.K.M. R. 173. Defendant stated that in the past, Landon has hit and
scratched A.K.M., B.M.M., and scratched some of A.K.M.’s friends. R.
173. Defendant denied causing the bruise. R. 174.
Thereafter, Plaintiff’s counsel moved to admit Exhibit 10 into the
record, and it was admitted. R. 11. R. 13 Plaintiff testified that the
17
Exhibit 10 depicted a bruise on A.K.M. that he thought happened at
school but had since learned that Defendant spanked her with a belt
buckle. R. 11. However, Plaintiff admitted that he was not present to
witness the event. R. 11. Defendant testified that A.K.M. received this
injury in either third or fourth grade by another student who stepped on
her leg. R. 174. Defendant stated that she reported the injury to A.K.M.’s
after-school teacher. R. 174. Defendant denied causing the injury. R. 174.
On or about September 28, 2023, Plaintiff placed A.K.M. in
counseling at Healing Hearts in Alex City, Alabama. R. 38. R. 86. Her
Counselor, Heather Dixon (“Dixon”), had four appointments with A.K.M.
prior to the final trial. R. 86. During direct examination by Plaintiff’s
counsel of Dixon, she testified that after the initial intake, she made a
report to DHR since she was a mandatory reporter. R. 89. However, at
the time of the final trial, which was more than a month after the report
was made, DHR had not investigated. R. 96. After the final trial but
before the Final Decree of Divorce was issued, DHR found that Defendant
was “Not Indicated for Physical Abuse, Bruises, or Cuts on A.K.M.” C.
081-082, Doc. 149.
18
Dixon testified that she “works with the parent and the child to
come to some kind of resolution.” R. 87. Yet, her recommendation was for
Defendant to have supervised visitation with both children even though
she had never met B.M.M. and her only conversations were with A.K.M.
and Plaintiff. R. 89. R. 90. Dixon admitted to not discussing any issues
with Defendant because she was still building rapport and trust with
A.K.M. R. 94.
During cross-examination by Defendant’s counsel, Dixon was
shown the video of A.K.M and Defendant spending time together at
Brooklyn’s birthday party. R. 91. When Dixon was asked by Defendant’s
counsel if she would be surprised that this video was recorded eight days
before Dixon’s first meeting with A.K.M., she responded, “Uh-huh”,
(indicating yes). R. 91.
In Defendant’s case-in-chief, Defendant’s counsel called Tasha
Howell (“Howell”) as a witness. R. 134. Howell and Defendant had been
friends for eight years and their daughters were on the dance team
together. R. 135. During competition season, Howell, Defendant, and
their daughters spent around five to six weekends together preparing for,
traveling to, and competing in dance competitions. R. 136. Howell stated
19
that these weekends were high stress for everyone involved but she never
witnessed Defendant lose her temper with A.K.M. R. 137. She further
stated that Defendant handled all of A.K.M.’s dance competitions, while
Plaintiff just watched the competitions. R. 138. Howell stated that she
saw a good relationship between A.K.M. and her mother. R. 136.
At the time of the final trial, the Parties had been separated since
August 16, 2023. R. 6. Plaintiff was living in the marital home with the
children pendente lite, and Defendant was living at her friend’s mother’s
home. R. 221. Both Parties were working. R. 17. R. 149. R. The Plaintiff
testified that he was earning about $105,000.00 annually and Defendant
testified that she was earning about $41,000.00 annually as a Manager
for Triton Management Group (“Triton”). R. 149. R. 17.
STATEMENT OF THE STANDARD OF REVIEW
When a [trial] court makes a custody determination
based on ore tenus evidence, its findings in support of that
determination are accorded a presumption of correctness on
appeal. Ex parte Bryowsky, 676 So. 2d 1322, 1324-26 (Ala.
1996). An appellate court will not reverse the [trial] court’s
custody judgment ‘unless the evidence so fails to support
the determination that it is plainly and palpably wrong, or
unless an abuse of the trial court’s discretion is shown. Id.
To substitute our judgment for that of the trial court would
be to reweigh the evidence. This Alabama law does not
allow.” Phillips v. Phillips, 622 So.2d 410, 412 (Ala.Civ.App.
1993).
20
SUMMARY OF THE ARGUMENT
In its Final Decree of Divorce, the trial court made no findings of
fact relating to child custody and the fitness of each party; it simply
stated that the Parties would be awarded joint legal custody and Plaintiff
would have sole physical custody of the minor children with Defendant
having visitation rights. Initial custody determinations are based on the
best interest of the child standard. Yet, applying the standard to the facts
in this case, an award other than joint physical custody of the minor
children was a determination that was plainly and palpably wrong.
Furthermore, if the trial court found that domestic or family
violence had occurred such that there was a rebuttable presumption
against Defendant having custody, the testimony and evidence presented
at the final trial was enough to rebut that presumption. Plaintiff alleged
instances of Defendant abusing their daughter. Yet, Plaintiff
continuously allowed Defendant to care for their children. Defendant
took them to school, hospital and dental appointments, as well as
weekend dance competitions. Further, several witnesses provided
testimony that Defendant and her daughter had a good mother-daughter
relationship, and they never saw any instances of abuse.
21
The trial court erroneously awarded Plaintiff sole physical custody
of the minor children when the evidence and testimony in this case have
shown that was not in the best interest of the children.
Taking the totality of the evidence presented, the trial court
erroneously found that Defendant did not rebut the presumption against
custody.
ARGUMENT
I. THE TRIAL COURT ERRED TO REVERSAL WHEN
IT AWARDED SOLE PHYSICAL CUSTODY TO
PLAINTIFF AND VISITATION TO DEFENDANT
INSTEAD OF JOINT PHYSICAL CUSTODY TO THE
PARTIES AS THAT WAS NOT IN THE BEST
INTEREST OF THE CHILDREN.
“When the trial court makes an initial custody determination,
neither party is entitled to a presumption in his or her favor, and the ‘best
interest of the child’ standard will generally apply.” Ex Parte Byars, 794
So.2d 345, 347 (Ala. 2001). However, the following factors must be
considered when determining the best interest of the children: the sex
and age of the children, the characteristics and needs of each child, the
relationship between each child and each parent, and the relationship
between the children. Ex Parte Devine, 398 So.2d 686, 696 (Ala. 1981).
Other factors that are important are the respective home environments
22
offered by the parties; each parent’s age, character, stability, mental and
physical health, and each parent’s ability to provide for the emotional,
social, moral, material and educational needs of the children. Id. at 697.
At the time of the final trial, the Parties had been separated for
roughly two and a half months. Plaintiff was living in the marital home
with the children pendente lite, and Defendant was living at her friend’s
mother’s home. The Parties were both employed. Plaintiff was making
about $105,000.00 annually and Defendant about $41,000.00 annually as
a Manager for Triton Management Group (“Triton”). Prior to Defendant
obtaining her position with Triton, she was a stay-at-home mother for
two years.
However, the Parties agree that for the majority of the marriage,
they both were employed and worked as a team to care for the home and
the children. Defendant took the children to school and to their doctor
and dental appointments. She was also responsible for getting A.K.M. to
her dance competitions. Plaintiff also testified that every night the
children Facetimed their mother to tell her goodnight.
There was concerning testimony that Plaintiff was actively
engaging in tactics to alienate A.K.M. from Defendant, which was not in
23
her best interest. Plaintiff purchased expensive gifts for A.K.M. ($150.00
pajama sets, make up, clothes, and dogs) and made negative comments
about Defendant in front of A.K.M. (you can go on your school fieldtrip if
your mom settles this case) that affected the relationship between A.K.M.
and the Defendant. Yet, when Plaintiff was not around, A.K.M. bonded
with the Defendant. It was only when the Plaintiff was around that
A.K.M. became distant.
Lastly, the Court heard from several witnesses that had been
friends with Defendant ranging from eight years to fifteen years. Their
sentiments were all the same. Green said that Defendant was a
wonderful mother. Porscha said that A.K.M. and Defendant had a great
and normal mother-daughter relationship. There was nothing out of the
ordinary that she noticed. Howell said that she had only seen a good
relationship between her and A.K.M.
Ultimately, there was substantial testimony and evidence
presented at the final trial that does not support the trial court’s Final
Decree of Divorce. After applying the applicable best interest of the child
factors to this case, it is clear that the trial court’s determination is
plainly and palpably wrong. Accordingly, the trial court erred to reversal
24
by failing to find that it was in the best interest of the children that the
Parties be awarded joint physical custody.
II. THE TRIAL COURT ERRED TO REVERSAL WHEN
IT AWARDED SOLE PHYSICAL CUSTODY TO
PLAINTIFF AND VISITATION TO DEFENDANT
WHEN THERE WAS SUFFICIENT EVIDENCE TO
OVERCOME THE REBUTTABLE PRESUMPTION
AGAINST DEFENDANT HAVING CUSTODY.
In its Final Decree of Divorce, the trial court made no findings of
fact relating to child custody and the fitness of each party; it simply
stated that the Parties would be awarded joint legal custody and Plaintiff
would have sole physical custody of the minor children with Defendant
having visitation rights. Pursuant to Alabama Code § 30-3-131 (1975),
In every proceeding where there is at issue a dispute as to the
custody of a child, a determination by the court that domestic
or family violence has occurred raises a rebuttable
presumption by the court that it is detrimental to the child and
not in the best interest of the child to be placed in sole custody,
joint legal custody, or joint physical custody with the
perpetrator of domestic or family violence. Notwithstanding
the provisions regarding rebuttable presumption, the judge
must also take into account what, if any, impact the domestic
violence had on the child.
ALA. CODE § 30-3-131(1975). However, if there is testimony and evidence
presented to the court that offsets any bad evidence or testimony, it can
25
be used to rebut the presumption against custody. Headrick v. Headrick,
916 So.2d 610, 614 (Ala.Civ.App. 2005).
In Headrick, the wife initiated a divorce action by filing a Petition
for Protection from Abuse against the husband, which was granted, and
the husband filed a Counterclaim for divorce. Id. at 612. The Court found
that both parties were physically abusive towards each other and had
difficulties with proper parenting. Id. The husband was aware that wife
abused prescription drugs but allowed her to keep the child. Id. The wife
was aware of the husband's temper but still allowed the child to stay with
him, even though her family was available to watch the child. Id. Each
party argued they were the better parent to have custody of the child. Id.
Ultimately, the court concluded that neither parent was better than the
other and awarded the Parties joint legal and physical custody of the
child. Id.
The Headrick case provides the appropriate rule of law governing
the decision on rebutting a presumption against a parent having custody.
In the present case, the Parties were seeking sole physical custody of the
minor children by claiming they were the fit and proper person to have
custody. Plaintiff presented testimony that Defendant was physically
26
abusive towards him and their daughter, which led him to file for divorce.
Notably, for two of the three incidents involving A.K.M., he was not
present to witness who injured her.
Plaintiff claims that Defendant grabbed their daughter’s arm
during an at-home dance practice in the basement. Plaintiff was not in
the basement. Defendant provided testimony that A.K.M.’s cousin,
Landon, caused the bruise on her arm while playing rough with her,
which is apparently a common occurrence with Landon. Further, the
testimony presented by the parties regarding the injury to A.K.M.’s leg,
was that it happened while she was in third or fourth grade. A.K.M. is
now in sixth grade. Defendant provided testimony that the injury
happened while at school, which mirrored Plaintiff’s testimony. Except,
Plaintiff conveniently stated that since this pending divorce, he found out
that Defendant caused the injury.
Interestingly, prior to this divorce action being initiated, the
Plaintiff allowed the children to be around the Defendant all the time.
Defendant took the children to school and to their doctor and dental
appointments. There was also testimony provided by Tasha Howell
(“Howell”) that Defendant was responsible for handling all of A.K.M.’s
27
dance competitions. She went on to say that during competition season it
was not uncommon for her, Defendant, and their daughters to spend five
to six weekends traveling to competitions together, which caused a lot of
stress for everybody. However, Howell never once saw Defendant lose her
temper with A.K.M.
Furthermore, there was testimony from Plaintiff that he allowed
A.K.M. to attend her friend, Brooklyn’s, birthday party after he filed for
divorce. Defendant was present at the party and spent that time bonding
with A.K.M. There was a video recording of Defendant and A.K.M.
rocking in a rocking chair at the party and looking at a story on a
cellphone together. This is particularly important since A.K.M.’s
counselor, Heather Dixon (“Dixon”), testified at the final trial that seeing
the video, which was recorded just a week before their initial
appointment, surprised her. At all times during A.K.M.’s interactions
with Dixon, Dixon had only spoken to A.K.M. and Plaintiff about issues
without any input from Defendant. Significantly, after the final trial was
over but before the Final Decree of Divorce was issued, Defendant’s
counsel submitted a letter from DHR to the Court that Defendant was
Not Indicated for Physical Abuse, Cuts, or Bruises of A.K.M.
28
Based on the totality of the evidence, Defendant rebutted the
presumption against custody, and the trial court was plainly and
palpably wrong for awarding Plaintiff sole physical custody of the minor
children. Accordingly, the trial court erred to reversal by failing to find
that Defendant overcame the rebuttable presumption against custody.
CONCLUSION
Based on the arguments and authorities cited herein, the trial
court’s Final Order is due to be reversed.
